We are informed by gentleman recent
ly from Alabama and Georgia, 4, At there is
prospect of the Cherokees becoming SOC n
organized into little Republic Of their own.
Their head chief is half blood of consider
able wealth and very respectable talents,
which have been brought to the best account
by a liberal education. He is now engaged,
with good prospect of success, IN civilizing
his red brethren, and organizing them, upon
the same principles with the existing States,
and if he succeeds in this, they will apply to
the general government to be admitted as
Territory. A number of the Indians of this
tribe are wealthy, raise cotton. and own
large numbers of slaves. An Alabama pa
per, in noticing these facts, says: 1--WE wish
them all success. We have very little doubt
but they will frame constitution and code
OF laws, under which they can live contented
and happy. In fact, we would as soon un-
dertake to form a Republic of the Cherokee
nation, as of some Of the South American
Provinces. The Cherokee population in
1924, exclusive Of blacks, was 3789 OF
these, something more than one-third re-
tanned the original manners and habits OF
their nation, and from their love of hunting,
and aversion to labor, they will no doubt be,
ere long, persuaded to migrate to the West,
and join their friends beyond the Mssissip-
pl The remainder consisting of all those
VINO have any love for improvement in the
arts of civilized life, are determined to live
aud die in the land of their forefathers. And
as they have such determination to become
permanent neighbors, We hope they may
prosper in whatever may tend to render
hem peaceable ones"
THE CHEROKEES.

In Petersburg, Mrs. LYDIA, wife Of Mr.. IS
RAEL HOUGHTON. The circumstances at
tending her death were very singular Mr.. II.
had Just returned from meeting; went to the
closet for refreshment, and while eating became
choked. Afte recovering, he turned to his
wife, and sad 'If that violent cough had contin-
ued one moment longer, you would have been
widow" "Then," said she, ''we would have
both gone together" and Immediately expired.

dom, and the good effects from the revival OF

Mr.. Huskisson had met with an accident,
having had his knee injured by the kick OF a

The divorce bill of Miss Turner, against
Wakefield, has passed the House OF Com
mons. 1t now only awaits the Royal assent
to pass into law.


Two Englishmen ofdistinction ,one of them
the brother of Peer, have been murdered
at Aleppo.


The London Gazette of the sth contains
an order in council, pursuant to treaties, TOR
sbolshing the anchorage dues claimed III
the Islands of Jersey, Guernsey, Alderny,
and Sark, on ships belonging to Denmark,
Prussia, Hanover, Sweden. Norway. the
United States of America, the Free Han
seattle Republics, the State of Colombia, and
the United States of Rio de la Plata.


FRANCE.-The opposition in France
seems to increase The ultras are still ex-
cited on account of the removal of Hyde de
Neuvillc.


PORTUGAL.


The provision for the maintenance ofthe Brit
ish troops stationed in Portugal, passed the
Commons without division, and was sanctioned
by the House of Lords. The seeding Minister.
voted for the supplies. The Editor Of the Liy
erpool Courier says


awe are glad, however, to find that what ap
pears to be the right principle, has been very
explicitly assented to on both sides-that ou
interference is confined to the protection of on
July so.

T.abourers, says the Pittsburg paper, are want.
ed Immediately on every section of the canal
stout industrious boys will be employed.


A stalk of corn is now growing upon the
ground of the editor Of the Reading Journal,
which measures 13 feet in height already.


The Essex county N. J. Republican mentions
that several cattle have lately been bit by mad
dogs in the western parts of that county; the an
imals that were bit, showed symptoms ofhydro-
phobia, and were killed.


The crops of grain, says the Pottstown Auro.
ra, have been safely got in, in our neighborhoods
never have we seen such an abundant harvest.


recent British traveller in Burmah, speaks
of the extraordinary unconcern with which the
Burmese, condemned to be shot or decapitated,
go to execution. They smoke segar on the
way, and continue to do so, with perfect sang
.5tOid, until the fatal moment.


Captain Rugan, of the brig Colombian, from

turn, the British Minister, embarked at Laguira
on the 5th inst. on board the British Frigate

thagena, accompanied by considerable num-
Der of troops


A German student at Berlin; has started
doubt whether we are not six years older thsn
we think ourselves. According to his calcula-
tions, the birth of our Saviour happened six years
earlier than has hitherto been assumed, and that
consequently, the present year is not 1927, but
1883.

ton in Worcester, Massachusetts, as common
drunkard, is hereafter to be discharged without
a certificate from doctor that he has submitted
to medical treatment fer cure.

counts Of tho crops throughout the kingdom,

CLEANING GS.

The meIjoration of the condition of the
African race became an object of solicitudc
Win the Society of Friends, as a body, early
afrer their establishment in this country
Several regulations were from time to time
adoptcd, with this view, one Of which, we
helieve, was, that no member possessed OF
alaye should sell it. But, It was not until
early in the last century, that a rule was de-
Gnitely adopted, that no member OF the So
ciety should hold fellow being in bondage.
This article of their discipline, which - a.
dopted throughout the Union, has in many
instances, subjected the society and lndivld-
uals to great expense and inconvenience,
owing to the obstacles thrown 10 the way OF
emancipation by the laws OF most OF the
Southern States. These require that II
master sets slave free, he shall remove
him from the State, or give heavy bonds to
guard against his ever be ecomns chargeable,
and also. we believe, hold the master still
accountable for any misconduct OF the eman'
cpated slave.


With these requsitinns. it was impnssi'
bic for many individuals to comply, and the
burthen consequently devolved on the ooci'
etv. 1t was most felt in the Yearly Meeting
of North Carolina, where the number oi
slaves who fell into their hands was great
est. Trustees were appointed TO nave inc
care Of those who were set tree, TIL they
could be removed from the State, and be-
yond the danger Of being again brought into
slavery. The number under care OF the
trustees had accumulated to more than
thousand A part of them tell into the
hands Of members, by inheritance, from
those who were not members. and part
belonged to individuals who were in posses
Cat. tha,r sptnn g
Two or three years since, measures were
adopted for their speedy removal We
have now before us an address from the last
Yearly Meeting. from which it appears that
about 500 persons have been removed during
the year preceding, at an expense OF $500.
Being left to their choice Of places, about DO
were taken to Liberia, (Africa,) 1l9 to Hay
ii, II to Philadelphia. and the remainder to
Ohio and Indiana During the year. the
donations in aid of this benevolent WORK
were from an individual in Philatielphla,
S2.914; from the Yearly Meeting of Ne%-
England, $1,000 from the Yearly Meeting
Of New York, $3.50; from the Yearly Meet
ing Of Philadelphia, $500; and from an mdi-
vidual in Burlington. NJ ]. 500. About
500 of the remaining free people OF colour
are willing to remove to free governments;
above 800 Of them to Liberia and 200 to
other places. A donation of $500 has been
made to the Colonization Society towards
chartering vessel tor Liberia, and $500
more is pledged if necessary. This vessel
we believe. has since sailed A further sum
ot two thousand dollars was found necessary
to complete the removal of the whole num-
ber, which has been apportonedto to be raised
among the several Quarterly Meetings.


In conclusion, the address says--"Not-
wi,hstanding all the varied difficulties at
tending this subject, it appears to US that
the blessing of Divine Providence has attend
cd our exertions in peculiar manner.-lf
the Father of Mercies should continue to
smile on our operations, we shall in year
or two more, in all probability, be released
from the heavier part of this burthen, and
feel the inexpressiblc consolation of having
plucked from the jaws of slavery, thousand
of our fellow beings, and placed them in free
governments, where they may enjoy the
privileges of citizens, and the additional sat-
isfaction of having been instrumental in per-
forming work which will doubtless have
very striking influence on the community
at large, and assist in paving the way for
the mitigation or removal of one of the great
est evils that ever affected the human race"


Massachusetts Sly.
EMANCIPATION.

escaped at great personal hazard. The pop.
ular party afterwards imprisoned him in
the castle of Naples. He was liberated when
the Carbonar ri took disastrous turn. Gen.
Church has been, from that period to the
present, out of employ. He is regarded as
an officer of great sagacity, enterprise and
courage. 1t is however somewhat curious,
to see person distinguished fer his attach
ment to the cause Of Neapolitan despotism.
now commanding the free spirits of Greece.
Gen. Church is Of Irish family. There is a
very interesting account of his adventures
and escape from Sicily, during the troubles
of 1920, to be found in some of the later
numbers Of the London Magazine.


W Y. ENQUIRER

New-Y York visited Trenton Falls from Uti-
ca; land from some cause not yet known,
Miss Eliza M SQydam, the daughter of one
of the most respectable citizens OF the for
mcr place, was preciptated from the top of
the Great Fall into the abyss below" The
body was found about forty rods from the
place where she fell in. and was TO be bu
ried in Utica on Monday afternoon. This
interesting Young lady was only about IL
years of age. ard her premature and disas.
trous fate produced general gloom in the
city Of N. York, when the intelligence OF it
reached that place.


From the Utica papers We learn some ad-
litional particulars, relating to the me'an-
choly accident which happened at the falls
on Saturday last. Miss L, Suydam and her
sister. on their visit to the falls, were at
tended by young gentleman. They had
arrived at the fourth fall. and passed in safe
" ali the points where the passage is diff
cult On reaching a spot where the pas
sage is very narrow. it was proposed to re-
turn Tothis Miss Suydam objected. adding
that she was never so delighted i'll her life,
and wished to prolong the pleasure. Her
sister at that moment relinqu,shed the arm
of the gentleman, and after passing few
steps with Miss Suydam, he turned his head
backward to discover how the former lady
was advancing, when he felt slight com
preston on his arm, and heard violent
shrek from the sister who had remained be-
hind. Instantly turning to the water, when
he perceived no trace of his former compan-
ion, miss Eliza Suydam,) but her bonnet
| floating on the top of the stream. WITHIN
the brief moment that his face had been a
verted, the body had sunk, and the water
which its fall had disturbed, closed over II.
"There was rushing sound, sulen plunge,
and all was over" So sudden and instanta-
necus was the disappearance, that no cry OF
agony, not even an audible sound, burst
! from the lips of the unfortunate lady.


ut may not be improper" says the Utica
Sentinel, "to say, that this is the first acct
dent that ever occurred in the thousands OF
visits that have been made to Trenton Falls
that it happened at a point where there
has never been considered to be, and where
in fact there is not, any danger"


From the Ncw-York Evening Post.
Lines on the untimely death of Miss. Suyd m,


who, while viewing the celebrated Trenton
Falls, lost her foothold, and was precipitatcd d
into the torrent.


The cataract's roar conveys dcafening sound


To those who wander near the craggy Steep
Beneath whose towering crest the waters bouno'


And with tumultuous rush the rocks o'erleap.
joyful throng the beetling cliffs ascend


TO hear below the raging torrents roar
To see the rocks o'er lashing surges bend,


While to the clouds their lofty SUBMITS soar
Hut see that fair one on the cliff appear,


With wandrlng gaze the splendid scene sur


vey;


So strong in virtue that she knows not fear,
Nor counts the dangers that beneath h'r iay'
But, oh! the precipice's brink beware,


Nor with unheedin 6 rashness tempt your fate;
The place is steep and dangerous, OH forbear'


But, Gracious God! the warning comes too


late!


The waves are parted by her lovely form,


And bv the currents force she's rudey driven
Her body to a watery grave has gone,


But her pure spirit is enshrin'd in Heaven!
And may her friends consolation find,


From Him who from the rocks made waters


flow;


Who gives relief to the desparing mind,


Heals every grief, and solaces each woe.
MELANCHOLY.

On Saturday last, the United States snip
North. Carolina, of "a guns. Com. Rogers
arrived at Norfolk in So days from Gibral-
tar. The N. c. has been absent from the
U. States % months, during which time the
officers and crew have generally enjoyed
good health.


The U. S. ship Eric, lying at the Navy
Yard. N. York, is ordered to be got ready
for sea with all possible DESPATCH to join ou'
West India squadron.

Thursday, Aug. 2, 1897.

well--we have seen some pretty good IN
market, the ears being we'll filled with
large full grains. Whilst we are enjoying
full and plenty, we should not forget those
in remoter regions. who have been less for
tunate. In Georgia the season has been less
propitious than with US. Lamcntable &C
counts are given of excessive dry weather
and failure of crops. The Macon Telegraph
says.-"From almost every part of the state,
We hear the most melancholy accounts of
the extensive and long continued drought,
and the utter prostration os the hopes Of the
the farmer-the structure on which the
prosperity Of the whole community is based.
With few exceptions. the Drought is very
general. In some Districts no rain has fallen
| for many weeks; the earth has become fair
| ly baked, and vegetation entirely suspended.
Whole corn fields are entirely destroyed
the corn blades, contorted and scorched, fall
to the ground; and the shrvelled stalks
smoke with heat. The cotton plant, from
its slower growth and deeper roots, suffers
later than the corn, butt also begins to feel
the effects of the draught. The leaves burn
up, and flowers wither and fall, leaving no
boil in their place. The animal as we'll as
the vegetable kingdom pants with the ex-
cessivc heat and drought. Inhabitants of
ponds and sire ans are boiled in their own
element, or perish by its evaporation. Cat
tie crop the juiceiess herbage, and look to
man in vain for succor; their emaciated car
casses and sunken eyeballs, as they watch
the rrluctan, clouds speak the keenness of
their suiferings. Large streams have sunk
to narrow ri,ls, and fountains are drying up.
Instead Of dew, mpalpable dust lifted into
the air by its dryness and buoyancy, falls on
the thirsty herbagc. Indeed the atmosphere
in many parts. travellers assure US, is SO fill
ed with dust, that respiration is extremely
difficult"


The crops Of wheat, rye, oats. &c
which have been gathered with us. are
great; and should the present be as favora-
! ble as the last month, more abundant crop
of coin and potatoes will be. gathered in this
section of the country than has ever been
known before. Our farmers have much
reason to thank the great giver of every
good for the bountiful blessings which he
has bestowed upon them.

Mr. Editor--Our friend O., it appears,
has again come forward and suppose has
arranged the thing entirely to his own salts
faction He asks "what is to prevent all
the water in the race from flowing upon
the wheeli" and then replies. "why gate,
to be sure; gate to open and yet make no
aperture" Excellent reasoning: quite wor-
thy a man Of his extensive "knowledge o.
mechanics and the pressure of fluids" But
il docs not follow, OF course, that because "a
gate prevents all the water in the race from
flowing upon the Wheel" that the Commit
tee can take what quantity they please. or
decide on what aperture they shall have,
without the consent Of other parties in the
concern; and as there are other parties
whose rights must be respected, and who
if my information is correct, positively re-
fuse to enter into any arrangement tor detln-
ing the aperture by any certain number OF
inches. I think our friend Q. himself, will
| be somewhat pcrpleXed to direct the Com
mittee what aperture they should make use
of under the existing circumstances. l can
now inform him that have "taken time to
examine soberly," "and must confe IS have not
penetration enough to discover his useful
facts and obvious deductions, and perhaps tor
this plain reason.--tbat at the commence
mcnt he bcgs the question. 1.-THE mill was
as he first stated, entitled to los inches or a.
ny other defined aperture, no mechanic
would for moment hesitate to say that the
water should be tax en- from the head, and
Of this he should have informed himself be-
fore he volunteered his services publicly to
instruct the Committee in their duty.

For Tie i Elmingtoa,Qn.

The weather, at this time, is extre meiy
warm and dry; yet we do not hear any COM
plaints from our farmers that rain is very
much wanted. A good shower Just now'
would be seasonable tor Buckwheat ans


rurnip seed, which it is time were IN the
ground. Corn looks very healthy and thrlyes

ally from the invasion and Vaccinations of for
eign power, and that it is not TO be considered
as an interference with the right of the people
of Portugal, if they choose it, even to go
wrong, and to reject the constitution altogeth-
er."

GREECE.


According to the accounts contained in the
English papers by the last arrival. it would
appear that the affairs of Greece are ap-
preaching a favorable crisis. The most au-
thentic statements agree in asserting that
the Greeks under Generals Church, Karais-
kaki, and others, having attacked Redschid
before Athens on the 18th Of April, and the
two following days, had compelled him to
retreat two hours march from the city. The
Greeks might thus convey supplies into the
Acrepolis, and finally, it was possible, de-
liver it. BY sea like success had attended
them, ten vessels with warlike stores, in
tended for the Seraskier. having been taken
or destroyed in the Gulf of Volo. The Aus
trian Observer of the goth of May contains
a proclamation Of Cochrane's On the affair
before Athens, declaring it to commence a
new ara in the military system of Greece
The former Committee of Government has
been succeeded by one composed Of George
Marc Michali, MorIote, son of the Bey of
Mama; Naku, a Ronieliote, and Marki, an
Ipsariote. Cochrane is said to have planned
a great expedition by sea and land, for the
deliverance of Athens, and the decision of the
fate of Greece. 1t was confidently reported
that Russia had dccisively apprised the
Porte, that the independence Of the Greeks
must be acknowledged, and that the appoint
ing of Capo dIstria at the head of the Greek
government, had had favorable influence
on the Russian Cabinet. The army on the
Pruth was said to be on its march towards
the Turkish borders. This on dit is as prob
able as that it is in contemplation in order
TO bring Austria in favor of the Greeks, to
make the son of Napoleon the King of the
Grecian REPUBLIC. Nothing staggers the Gre
dulity OF a continental journalist. Letters
from Vienna state the argument of the
Turkish Divan against recognising the inde-
pendence of Greece, to be the imposslbility
Of ascertaining who are the heads of its go.
vernment. 1t appears that party OF Turk
ish prisoners Of war, had been ,wantonly
: butchercd by the Greeks in defiance of the
; captulation. In consequence Of this outrage,
General Church threatened to leave the ar
my, if those concerned in it we're not arrest
ed. This had been done. The General had
issued proclamation on leaving his head
quarters at Megara, to march to Athens
Bali. finer.


By later .frrival.


PARIS, June 14.-We were unwilling yester-
day to repeat the disastrous news from Athens,
which the Augsburgh Gazette gave on the faith
of letters from syria of the 18th and 29th of May,
received at Trieste on the Sd inst. We have
been in the habit Of receiving with caution eve
~ thing which emanates from city, whose OF.
fetal paper, under the influence of NJ. de Met
tcrnich, often substitute its wishes for the real.
ity. In general, we should endeavor to be on
our guard in receiving the various reports that
are in circulation relative to the affairs of Greece.


We thought that the Austrian Observer would
furnish us to-day with some particulars. We an
NFt
Acropolis, if, as is stated, it has yielded to the
exertions of the Seraskier, and if the brave Ka.
raskaki has fallen, with three thousand of his
men under the walls of Athens.


We have the Observer of the 5th before us,
which is silent as to the affairs OF Greece May
not this silence augur well.


The difference in the dates Of the two letters
from Syra (the first being Of the 18th, and the
second of the 29tl of Aiay) also excites some
doubts as to the authenticity of its intelligence.
The interval of ten days between the two letters
which announce such important events, and
which arrived at the same moment at Trieste, is
not explained.


The followingis is an extract of another letter
1 from Trieste, dated the Sd of June:-


| srhe AcropoIis still held out on the 18th of
May, after the sangunary defeat OF the Greek ar
my 1t was reported at Syria that the Greek Ad-
miral dc Rigny and Com, Hamilton had arrived
at the Pireus for the purpose of obtaining an
honorable capitlaton for the brave defenders
of the Acropolis, but the Seraskier WIS not dis
posed to grant it. No circumstantal details of
the unfortunate events which have taken place
under the walls of Athens, are yet known; it is
only asccrtaned that the first attack of the
Greeks against the camp of the Turks promised
the most happy result, but the Seraskier having
during the action, received reinforcement Of
| 5000 men, the Greeks were compelled 70 sur
render" Alas it is no longer possible for us to
doubt the defeat Of the Greeks before Athens;
this sad news is confirmed from all quarters.


"lt is affirmed that the details given in the
, German journals are incorrect; but it is too true
that $500 Greeks have pershed. At the last
advces, 5000 Greeks, under Gen Church, sur
rounded the heights of phaleres. On the 10th
of May (tcn days after the defeat of the Greeks)
the Acropolic still held out. 1t was said that
1000 Greeks had marched towards Asomato, the
north Of the Pyreus in order to attack the Turks
in the rear whilst the other corps should attack
them in 'front.' On the 4th Karaskaki attacked
the Turks and persisted, together with 500 of his
men. On the 9th the action took place with
the troops who had effected landing. Fight
thousand men, sent by Redschid Pacha attacked
them and the defeat ofthe Greeks was horrible:
of % Philhellenes, IS were killed. Lord Coch-
rane escaped with difficulty by swimming to one
of his vessels, and Gen Church, in ralying the
Greeks, narrowly escaped capture. This dlsas-
4
GREECE.

"a Subscriber" inquiries who is the Gen:
Church. now commanding the land forces OF
the Creeks Sir Richard Churcn',s an offl-
Ger who had greatly distinguished himself
during the war of England with France


He raised regiment in the Ionian Islands.
known by the name of the Greek Light In
fantry. After the peace of 1915 he entered


into the service of the King OF Naples, and
was appointed governor general OF the east
ern provinces of the kingdom. He was sub
sequently appointed to the command Of the
Neapolitan forces in Sicily, and was pres
ent at the revolution in Palermo, whence he

he should be innl edia:eiy executed by being
burnt TO death--the sable culprit was led to
"A tree and tied to it, and large quantity of
pine knots collected, and placed around him,
and the fatal torch was applied to the pile,
even against the remonstrances OF several
gentlemen who were present; and the mis-
cradle being was in a short time burnt to
ashes.


An inquest was held over the remains,
and the Sheriff of Perry County, with a
company of about twenty men, repaired to
the peighborhood where this barbarous act
took place. to secure those concerned, but
with what success we have not heard, but
we hope he will succeed in bringing the per-
pctrators of 80 high-handed a measure to
account to their country for their conduct in
this affair. This is the second negro who
has been thus put to death without judge or
jury III that county.


a Coroner's inquest was held on the 18th
inst. in Henrioo county, Virginia, over the
body Of free man of color, of the name OF
Isaac Reed, who it appears came his
death in consequence Of being severely lash
ed with a cowhde, and having rope tied
about his arms, extending across the throat,
to the Lobe Of each ear. leaving strong im-
preston OH the neck, and causing the tongue,
which was much swollen. to project beyond
the teeth. The persons concerned IN this at
fair were VIM. Grace, S. Fl. Whipple, and
d. Henderson: the injury was inflicted at
the house of the former. They have all
been committed to prison.

full articles.headline: THE CHEROKEES.
full articles.article:
We are informed by gentleman recent
ly from Alabama and Georgia, 4, At there is
prospect of the Cherokees becoming SOC n
organized into little Republic Of their own.
Their head chief is half blood of consider
able wealth and very respectable talents,
which have been brought to the best account
by a liberal education. He is now engaged,
with good prospect of success, IN civilizing
his red brethren, and organizing them, upon
the same principles with the existing States,
and if he succeeds in this, they will apply to
the general government to be admitted as
Territory. A number of the Indians of this
tribe are wealthy, raise cotton. and own
large numbers of slaves. An Alabama pa
per, in noticing these facts, says: 1--WE wish
them all success. We have very little doubt
but they will frame constitution and code
OF laws, under which they can live contented
and happy. In fact, we would as soon un-
dertake to form a Republic of the Cherokee
nation, as of some Of the South American
Provinces. The Cherokee population in
1924, exclusive Of blacks, was 3789 OF
these, something more than one-third re-
tanned the original manners and habits OF
their nation, and from their love of hunting,
and aversion to labor, they will no doubt be,
ere long, persuaded to migrate to the West,
and join their friends beyond the Mssissip-
pl The remainder consisting of all those
VINO have any love for improvement in the
arts of civilized life, are determined to live
aud die in the land of their forefathers. And
as they have such determination to become
permanent neighbors, We hope they may
prosper in whatever may tend to render
hem peaceable ones"

full articles.headline: DIED,
full articles.article:
On Thursday night last, in this Borough, Mr..
THOMAS RUMFORD, son Of Mr.. John Rum
ford, Halter.


On Friday morning last JAMES EDWARD,
infrnt son of the Rev; Solomon Higgins, of this
Borough


On saturday morning last, CATHARINE,
youngest daughter of MIR. William Kirk, of this
place.


On Monday last, Miss MARIA MORRISON.
daughter of Mr.. Thomas Morrison, of this Bo,
rough.


On Monday last, at his residence near NewcaE
tie, Mr.. SAMUEL NIVIN.
On Wednesday, Mrs. SUSANNA ELLIOTT.
of Brandywinc Hundred


On Sunday evening, the 22d inst after short
illness, Mrs. REBECCA WILMER, consort Of
the Rev. Simon Wilmer, of Swedesboro, N. j.
In Philadelphia, on the eth ult. ANN, infant
Daughter of BENJAMIN II. SPRINGER, aged
Ia months.


In Madbury, Mass. Mr.. ISRAEL TIBBETS.
aged 50, probably the largest man in America.
his weight exceeding 450 lbs.
In Petersburg, Mrs. LYDIA, wife Of Mr.. IS
RAEL HOUGHTON. The circumstances at
tending her death were very singular Mr.. II.
had Just returned from meeting; went to the
closet for refreshment, and while eating became
choked. Afte recovering, he turned to his
wife, and sad 'If that violent cough had contin-
ued one moment longer, you would have been
widow" "Then," said she, ''we would have
both gone together" and Immediately expired.

full articles.headline: TUSCALOOSA, (Alab.) June 80.
full articles.article:

laSt week one of those outrageous transac-


.ons-and we really think, disgracefnl to
The character of civilized man, took place
near the North East boundary line of Perry,
Adjoining Bibb and Antauga counties. The
circumstances, we are informed, by gen


aeman ss,n from that county, are: "Ihat Mr..

brother, found the negro driving his masters
wagon. they seized him, and either did, or
' aere about to chastise him, when the negro
sssooed ssd M'Neily, so that he died in an hour
;sNerwards--the negro was taken before a


lus'lce OF the teace. who, after serious de-
,huerat,on, waved his authority; ferhots
,h Trough tear, as the crowd of persons from

,ic., uc. oi 70 or 80 near Mr. Peoples (the JUS
W. N.s@ house. He acted as President of the

full articles.headline:
FOREIGN lNTELLTGENCE.

FROM ENGLAND.
full articles.article:
. The English papers give highly favorable
accounts of the crops throughout the king
dom, and the good effects from the revival OF
trade, were becoming more and more mani
fest.


Mr.. Huskisson had met with an accident,
having had his knee injured by the kick OF a
horse.


The divorce bill of Miss Turner, against
Wakefield, has passed the House OF Com
mons. 1t now only awaits the Royal assent
to pass into law.


Two Englishmen ofdistinction ,one of them
the brother of Peer, have been murdered
at Aleppo.


The London Gazette of the sth contains
an order in council, pursuant to treaties, TOR
sbolshing the anchorage dues claimed III
the Islands of Jersey, Guernsey, Alderny,
and Sark, on ships belonging to Denmark,
Prussia, Hanover, Sweden. Norway. the
United States of America, the Free Han
seattle Republics, the State of Colombia, and
the United States of Rio de la Plata.


FRANCE.-The opposition in France
seems to increase The ultras are still ex-
cited on account of the removal of Hyde de
Neuvillc.


PORTUGAL.


The provision for the maintenance ofthe Brit
ish troops stationed in Portugal, passed the
Commons without division, and was sanctioned
by the House of Lords. The seeding Minister.
voted for the supplies. The Editor Of the Liy
erpool Courier says


awe are glad, however, to find that what ap
pears to be the right principle, has been very
explicitly assented to on both sides-that ou
interference is confined to the protection of on

full articles.headline: CLEANING GS.
full articles.article:
T.abourers, says the Pittsburg paper, are want.
ed Immediately on every section of the canal
stout industrious boys will be employed.


A stalk of corn is now growing upon the
ground of the editor Of the Reading Journal,
which measures 13 feet in height already.


The Essex county N. J. Republican mentions
that several cattle have lately been bit by mad
dogs in the western parts of that county; the an
imals that were bit, showed symptoms ofhydro-
phobia, and were killed.


The crops of grain, says the Pottstown Auro.
ra, have been safely got in, in our neighborhoods
never have we seen such an abundant harvest.


recent British traveller in Burmah, speaks
of the extraordinary unconcern with which the
Burmese, condemned to be shot or decapitated,
go to execution. They smoke segar on the
way, and continue to do so, with perfect sang
.5tOid, until the fatal moment.


Captain Rugan, of the brig Colombian, from
I.aguira, states that Gen. Bolivar. and Mr.. Cock
turn, the British Minister, embarked at Laguira
on the 5th inst. on board the British Frigate
Druid, Capt. Chambers, bound down to Car
thagena, accompanied by considerable num-
Der of troops


A German student at Berlin; has started
doubt whether we are not six years older thsn
we think ourselves. According to his calcula-
tions, the birth of our Saviour happened six years
earlier than has hitherto been assumed, and that
consequently, the present year is not 1927, but
1883.


i>o person confined in the House Of Correc-
ton in Worcester, Massachusetts, as common
drunkard, is hereafter to be discharged without
a certificate from doctor that he has submitted
to medical treatment fer cure.


The English papers give highly favorable &C.
counts Of tho crops throughout the kingdom,
and the good effects from the revival Of trade
were beco ming more and more manifest.

full articles.headline: EMANCIPATION.
full articles.article:
The meIjoration of the condition of the
African race became an object of solicitudc
Win the Society of Friends, as a body, early
afrer their establishment in this country
Several regulations were from time to time
adoptcd, with this view, one Of which, we
helieve, was, that no member possessed OF
alaye should sell it. But, It was not until
early in the last century, that a rule was de-
Gnitely adopted, that no member OF the So
ciety should hold fellow being in bondage.
This article of their discipline, which - a.
dopted throughout the Union, has in many
instances, subjected the society and lndivld-
uals to great expense and inconvenience,
owing to the obstacles thrown 10 the way OF
emancipation by the laws OF most OF the
Southern States. These require that II
master sets slave free, he shall remove
him from the State, or give heavy bonds to
guard against his ever be ecomns chargeable,
and also. we believe, hold the master still
accountable for any misconduct OF the eman'
cpated slave.


With these requsitinns. it was impnssi'
bic for many individuals to comply, and the
burthen consequently devolved on the ooci'
etv. 1t was most felt in the Yearly Meeting
of North Carolina, where the number oi
slaves who fell into their hands was great
est. Trustees were appointed TO nave inc
care Of those who were set tree, TIL they
could be removed from the State, and be-
yond the danger Of being again brought into
slavery. The number under care OF the
trustees had accumulated to more than
thousand A part of them tell into the
hands Of members, by inheritance, from
those who were not members. and part
belonged to individuals who were in posses
Cat. tha,r sptnn g
Two or three years since, measures were
adopted for their speedy removal We
have now before us an address from the last
Yearly Meeting. from which it appears that
about 500 persons have been removed during
the year preceding, at an expense OF $500.
Being left to their choice Of places, about DO
were taken to Liberia, (Africa,) 1l9 to Hay
ii, II to Philadelphia. and the remainder to
Ohio and Indiana During the year. the
donations in aid of this benevolent WORK
were from an individual in Philatielphla,
S2.914; from the Yearly Meeting of Ne%-
England, $1,000 from the Yearly Meeting
Of New York, $3.50; from the Yearly Meet
ing Of Philadelphia, $500; and from an mdi-
vidual in Burlington. NJ ]. 500. About
500 of the remaining free people OF colour
are willing to remove to free governments;
above 800 Of them to Liberia and 200 to
other places. A donation of $500 has been
made to the Colonization Society towards
chartering vessel tor Liberia, and $500
more is pledged if necessary. This vessel
we believe. has since sailed A further sum
ot two thousand dollars was found necessary
to complete the removal of the whole num-
ber, which has been apportonedto to be raised
among the several Quarterly Meetings.


In conclusion, the address says--"Not-
wi,hstanding all the varied difficulties at
tending this subject, it appears to US that
the blessing of Divine Providence has attend
cd our exertions in peculiar manner.-lf
the Father of Mercies should continue to
smile on our operations, we shall in year
or two more, in all probability, be released
from the heavier part of this burthen, and
feel the inexpressiblc consolation of having
plucked from the jaws of slavery, thousand
of our fellow beings, and placed them in free
governments, where they may enjoy the
privileges of citizens, and the additional sat-
isfaction of having been instrumental in per-
forming work which will doubtless have
very striking influence on the community
at large, and assist in paving the way for
the mitigation or removal of one of the great
est evils that ever affected the human race"


Massachusetts Sly.

escaped at great personal hazard. The pop.
ular party afterwards imprisoned him in
the castle of Naples. He was liberated when
the Carbonar ri took disastrous turn. Gen.
Church has been, from that period to the
present, out of employ. He is regarded as
an officer of great sagacity, enterprise and
courage. 1t is however somewhat curious,
to see person distinguished fer his attach
ment to the cause Of Neapolitan despotism.
now commanding the free spirits of Greece.
Gen. Church is Of Irish family. There is a
very interesting account of his adventures
and escape from Sicily, during the troubles
of 1920, to be found in some of the later
numbers Of the London Magazine.


W Y. ENQUIRER

full articles.headline: MELANCHOLY.
full articles.article:
New-Y York visited Trenton Falls from Uti-
ca; land from some cause not yet known,
Miss Eliza M SQydam, the daughter of one
of the most respectable citizens OF the for
mcr place, was preciptated from the top of
the Great Fall into the abyss below" The
body was found about forty rods from the
place where she fell in. and was TO be bu
ried in Utica on Monday afternoon. This
interesting Young lady was only about IL
years of age. ard her premature and disas.
trous fate produced general gloom in the
city Of N. York, when the intelligence OF it
reached that place.


From the Utica papers We learn some ad-
litional particulars, relating to the me'an-
choly accident which happened at the falls
on Saturday last. Miss L, Suydam and her
sister. on their visit to the falls, were at
tended by young gentleman. They had
arrived at the fourth fall. and passed in safe
" ali the points where the passage is diff
cult On reaching a spot where the pas
sage is very narrow. it was proposed to re-
turn Tothis Miss Suydam objected. adding
that she was never so delighted i'll her life,
and wished to prolong the pleasure. Her
sister at that moment relinqu,shed the arm
of the gentleman, and after passing few
steps with Miss Suydam, he turned his head
backward to discover how the former lady
was advancing, when he felt slight com
preston on his arm, and heard violent
shrek from the sister who had remained be-
hind. Instantly turning to the water, when
he perceived no trace of his former compan-
ion, miss Eliza Suydam,) but her bonnet
| floating on the top of the stream. WITHIN
the brief moment that his face had been a
verted, the body had sunk, and the water
which its fall had disturbed, closed over II.
"There was rushing sound, sulen plunge,
and all was over" So sudden and instanta-
necus was the disappearance, that no cry OF
agony, not even an audible sound, burst
! from the lips of the unfortunate lady.


ut may not be improper" says the Utica
Sentinel, "to say, that this is the first acct
dent that ever occurred in the thousands OF
visits that have been made to Trenton Falls
that it happened at a point where there
has never been considered to be, and where
in fact there is not, any danger"


From the Ncw-York Evening Post.
Lines on the untimely death of Miss. Suyd m,


who, while viewing the celebrated Trenton
Falls, lost her foothold, and was precipitatcd d
into the torrent.


The cataract's roar conveys dcafening sound


To those who wander near the craggy Steep
Beneath whose towering crest the waters bouno'


And with tumultuous rush the rocks o'erleap.
joyful throng the beetling cliffs ascend


TO hear below the raging torrents roar
To see the rocks o'er lashing surges bend,


While to the clouds their lofty SUBMITS soar
Hut see that fair one on the cliff appear,


With wandrlng gaze the splendid scene sur


vey;


So strong in virtue that she knows not fear,
Nor counts the dangers that beneath h'r iay'
But, oh! the precipice's brink beware,


Nor with unheedin 6 rashness tempt your fate;
The place is steep and dangerous, OH forbear'


But, Gracious God! the warning comes too


late!


The waves are parted by her lovely form,


And bv the currents force she's rudey driven
Her body to a watery grave has gone,


But her pure spirit is enshrin'd in Heaven!
And may her friends consolation find,


From Him who from the rocks made waters


flow;


Who gives relief to the desparing mind,


Heals every grief, and solaces each woe.

full articles.headline:
ryxu yyILMINGTcNxAN

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.

Thursday, Aug. 2, 1897.
full articles.article:
On Saturday last, the United States snip
North. Carolina, of "a guns. Com. Rogers
arrived at Norfolk in So days from Gibral-
tar. The N. c. has been absent from the
U. States % months, during which time the
officers and crew have generally enjoyed
good health.


The U. S. ship Eric, lying at the Navy
Yard. N. York, is ordered to be got ready
for sea with all possible DESPATCH to join ou'
West India squadron.

well--we have seen some pretty good IN
market, the ears being we'll filled with
large full grains. Whilst we are enjoying
full and plenty, we should not forget those
in remoter regions. who have been less for
tunate. In Georgia the season has been less
propitious than with US. Lamcntable &C
counts are given of excessive dry weather
and failure of crops. The Macon Telegraph
says.-"From almost every part of the state,
We hear the most melancholy accounts of
the extensive and long continued drought,
and the utter prostration os the hopes Of the
the farmer-the structure on which the
prosperity Of the whole community is based.
With few exceptions. the Drought is very
general. In some Districts no rain has fallen
| for many weeks; the earth has become fair
| ly baked, and vegetation entirely suspended.
Whole corn fields are entirely destroyed
the corn blades, contorted and scorched, fall
to the ground; and the shrvelled stalks
smoke with heat. The cotton plant, from
its slower growth and deeper roots, suffers
later than the corn, butt also begins to feel
the effects of the draught. The leaves burn
up, and flowers wither and fall, leaving no
boil in their place. The animal as we'll as
the vegetable kingdom pants with the ex-
cessivc heat and drought. Inhabitants of
ponds and sire ans are boiled in their own
element, or perish by its evaporation. Cat
tie crop the juiceiess herbage, and look to
man in vain for succor; their emaciated car
casses and sunken eyeballs, as they watch
the rrluctan, clouds speak the keenness of
their suiferings. Large streams have sunk
to narrow ri,ls, and fountains are drying up.
Instead Of dew, mpalpable dust lifted into
the air by its dryness and buoyancy, falls on
the thirsty herbagc. Indeed the atmosphere
in many parts. travellers assure US, is SO fill
ed with dust, that respiration is extremely
difficult"


The crops Of wheat, rye, oats. &c
which have been gathered with us. are
great; and should the present be as favora-
! ble as the last month, more abundant crop
of coin and potatoes will be. gathered in this
section of the country than has ever been
known before. Our farmers have much
reason to thank the great giver of every
good for the bountiful blessings which he
has bestowed upon them.

full articles.headline: For Tie i Elmingtoa,Qn.
full articles.article:
Mr. Editor--Our friend O., it appears,
has again come forward and suppose has
arranged the thing entirely to his own salts
faction He asks "what is to prevent all
the water in the race from flowing upon
the wheeli" and then replies. "why gate,
to be sure; gate to open and yet make no
aperture" Excellent reasoning: quite wor-
thy a man Of his extensive "knowledge o.
mechanics and the pressure of fluids" But
il docs not follow, OF course, that because "a
gate prevents all the water in the race from
flowing upon the Wheel" that the Commit
tee can take what quantity they please. or
decide on what aperture they shall have,
without the consent Of other parties in the
concern; and as there are other parties
whose rights must be respected, and who
if my information is correct, positively re-
fuse to enter into any arrangement tor detln-
ing the aperture by any certain number OF
inches. I think our friend Q. himself, will
| be somewhat pcrpleXed to direct the Com
mittee what aperture they should make use
of under the existing circumstances. l can
now inform him that have "taken time to
examine soberly," "and must confe IS have not
penetration enough to discover his useful
facts and obvious deductions, and perhaps tor
this plain reason.--tbat at the commence
mcnt he bcgs the question. 1.-THE mill was
as he first stated, entitled to los inches or a.
ny other defined aperture, no mechanic
would for moment hesitate to say that the
water should be tax en- from the head, and
Of this he should have informed himself be-
fore he volunteered his services publicly to
instruct the Committee in their duty.


July so. L.

The weather, at this time, is extre meiy
warm and dry; yet we do not hear any COM
plaints from our farmers that rain is very
much wanted. A good shower Just now'
would be seasonable tor Buckwheat ans


rurnip seed, which it is time were IN the
ground. Corn looks very healthy and thrlyes

ally from the invasion and Vaccinations of for
eign power, and that it is not TO be considered
as an interference with the right of the people
of Portugal, if they choose it, even to go
wrong, and to reject the constitution altogeth-
er."

full articles.headline: GREECE.
full articles.article:
GREECE.


According to the accounts contained in the
English papers by the last arrival. it would
appear that the affairs of Greece are ap-
preaching a favorable crisis. The most au-
thentic statements agree in asserting that
the Greeks under Generals Church, Karais-
kaki, and others, having attacked Redschid
before Athens on the 18th Of April, and the
two following days, had compelled him to
retreat two hours march from the city. The
Greeks might thus convey supplies into the
Acrepolis, and finally, it was possible, de-
liver it. BY sea like success had attended
them, ten vessels with warlike stores, in
tended for the Seraskier. having been taken
or destroyed in the Gulf of Volo. The Aus
trian Observer of the goth of May contains
a proclamation Of Cochrane's On the affair
before Athens, declaring it to commence a
new ara in the military system of Greece
The former Committee of Government has
been succeeded by one composed Of George
Marc Michali, MorIote, son of the Bey of
Mama; Naku, a Ronieliote, and Marki, an
Ipsariote. Cochrane is said to have planned
a great expedition by sea and land, for the
deliverance of Athens, and the decision of the
fate of Greece. 1t was confidently reported
that Russia had dccisively apprised the
Porte, that the independence Of the Greeks
must be acknowledged, and that the appoint
ing of Capo dIstria at the head of the Greek
government, had had favorable influence
on the Russian Cabinet. The army on the
Pruth was said to be on its march towards
the Turkish borders. This on dit is as prob
able as that it is in contemplation in order
TO bring Austria in favor of the Greeks, to
make the son of Napoleon the King of the
Grecian REPUBLIC. Nothing staggers the Gre
dulity OF a continental journalist. Letters
from Vienna state the argument of the
Turkish Divan against recognising the inde-
pendence of Greece, to be the imposslbility
Of ascertaining who are the heads of its go.
vernment. 1t appears that party OF Turk
ish prisoners Of war, had been ,wantonly
: butchercd by the Greeks in defiance of the
; captulation. In consequence Of this outrage,
General Church threatened to leave the ar
my, if those concerned in it we're not arrest
ed. This had been done. The General had
issued proclamation on leaving his head
quarters at Megara, to march to Athens
Bali. finer.


By later .frrival.


PARIS, June 14.-We were unwilling yester-
day to repeat the disastrous news from Athens,
which the Augsburgh Gazette gave on the faith
of letters from syria of the 18th and 29th of May,
received at Trieste on the Sd inst. We have
been in the habit Of receiving with caution eve
~ thing which emanates from city, whose OF.
fetal paper, under the influence of NJ. de Met
tcrnich, often substitute its wishes for the real.
ity. In general, we should endeavor to be on
our guard in receiving the various reports that
are in circulation relative to the affairs of Greece.


We thought that the Austrian Observer would
furnish us to-day with some particulars. We an
NFt
Acropolis, if, as is stated, it has yielded to the
exertions of the Seraskier, and if the brave Ka.
raskaki has fallen, with three thousand of his
men under the walls of Athens.


We have the Observer of the 5th before us,
which is silent as to the affairs OF Greece May
not this silence augur well.


The difference in the dates Of the two letters
from Syra (the first being Of the 18th, and the
second of the 29tl of Aiay) also excites some
doubts as to the authenticity of its intelligence.
The interval of ten days between the two letters
which announce such important events, and
which arrived at the same moment at Trieste, is
not explained.


The followingis is an extract of another letter
1 from Trieste, dated the Sd of June:-


| srhe AcropoIis still held out on the 18th of
May, after the sangunary defeat OF the Greek ar
my 1t was reported at Syria that the Greek Ad-
miral dc Rigny and Com, Hamilton had arrived
at the Pireus for the purpose of obtaining an
honorable capitlaton for the brave defenders
of the Acropolis, but the Seraskier WIS not dis
posed to grant it. No circumstantal details of
the unfortunate events which have taken place
under the walls of Athens, are yet known; it is
only asccrtaned that the first attack of the
Greeks against the camp of the Turks promised
the most happy result, but the Seraskier having
during the action, received reinforcement Of
| 5000 men, the Greeks were compelled 70 sur
render" Alas it is no longer possible for us to
doubt the defeat Of the Greeks before Athens;
this sad news is confirmed from all quarters.


"lt is affirmed that the details given in the
, German journals are incorrect; but it is too true
that $500 Greeks have pershed. At the last
advces, 5000 Greeks, under Gen Church, sur
rounded the heights of phaleres. On the 10th
of May (tcn days after the defeat of the Greeks)
the Acropolic still held out. 1t was said that
1000 Greeks had marched towards Asomato, the
north Of the Pyreus in order to attack the Turks
in the rear whilst the other corps should attack
them in 'front.' On the 4th Karaskaki attacked
the Turks and persisted, together with 500 of his
men. On the 9th the action took place with
the troops who had effected landing. Fight
thousand men, sent by Redschid Pacha attacked
them and the defeat ofthe Greeks was horrible:
of % Philhellenes, IS were killed. Lord Coch-
rane escaped with difficulty by swimming to one
of his vessels, and Gen Church, in ralying the
Greeks, narrowly escaped capture. This dlsas-
4

"a Subscriber" inquiries who is the Gen:
Church. now commanding the land forces OF
the Creeks Sir Richard Churcn',s an offl-
Ger who had greatly distinguished himself
during the war of England with France


He raised regiment in the Ionian Islands.
known by the name of the Greek Light In
fantry. After the peace of 1915 he entered


into the service of the King OF Naples, and
was appointed governor general OF the east
ern provinces of the kingdom. He was sub
sequently appointed to the command Of the
Neapolitan forces in Sicily, and was pres
ent at the revolution in Palermo, whence he

he should be innl edia:eiy executed by being
burnt TO death--the sable culprit was led to
"A tree and tied to it, and large quantity of
pine knots collected, and placed around him,
and the fatal torch was applied to the pile,
even against the remonstrances OF several
gentlemen who were present; and the mis-
cradle being was in a short time burnt to
ashes.


An inquest was held over the remains,
and the Sheriff of Perry County, with a
company of about twenty men, repaired to
the peighborhood where this barbarous act
took place. to secure those concerned, but
with what success we have not heard, but
we hope he will succeed in bringing the per-
pctrators of 80 high-handed a measure to
account to their country for their conduct in
this affair. This is the second negro who
has been thus put to death without judge or
jury III that county.


a Coroner's inquest was held on the 18th
inst. in Henrioo county, Virginia, over the
body Of free man of color, of the name OF
Isaac Reed, who it appears came his
death in consequence Of being severely lash
ed with a cowhde, and having rope tied
about his arms, extending across the throat,
to the Lobe Of each ear. leaving strong im-
preston OH the neck, and causing the tongue,
which was much swollen. to project beyond
the teeth. The persons concerned IN this at
fair were VIM. Grace, S. Fl. Whipple, and
d. Henderson: the injury was inflicted at
the house of the former. They have all
been committed to prison.
